awd_titl_txt: Marine Course-Based Undergraduate Research Experience (CURE) Targeting Transfer Students as a Means for Building a Science Learning Community.
awd_abstract_narration:
Today more than 50% of STEM students will attend more than one higher education institution to complete a bachelor's degree. Many of these students are transfer students who attend a 2-year community college and later transfer to a 4-year institution. Unfortunately, many transfer students fail to complete a bachelor's degree. A major reason for this phenomenon is that transfer students often face challenges that negatively affect their academic success, and ultimately their retention and graduation in a STEM major. Programs that increase the success of transfer students can significantly increase the STEM graduation rate, which will help meet the national goal of increasing the diversity and size of the STEM workforce. Participation in scientific research experiences involving real-world problems supports student success, increasing student retention and graduation rates. This project provides undergraduate research experiences to transfer students both during a summer bridge program and the academic year. These experiences will help establish a diverse and sustainable research community that will better support and prepare all undergraduates for STEM professions.

This project will take place at the University of West Florida (UWF), a medium-sized regional state university with a high percentage of transfer students. The central goal of this project is to establish a multi-faceted course-based undergraduate research (CURE) community centered on the novel genetics and cell biology of the local coquina clam Donax variabilis. This project will also address specific challenges to the academic success of transfer students, engage faculty with research and enhance their pedagogical skill, and develop strategies for institutional transformation and sustainability. The central project activities will: 1) develop and enhance student research and laboratory skills, and 2) engage incoming transfer students and faculty through a summer bridge program that incorporates peer mentoring and a CURE training workshop series for faculty based on the coquina research project. The project will contribute to a better understanding of the biology of the coquina clam. In addition, the project will contribute to education research on factors that influence the success of transfer students in higher education and generate best practices that other institutions might implement. The project will improve understanding of current challenges encountered by transfer students that impact their success in biology, the effect of the CURE experience and bridge program on transfer students' sense of belonging and their scientific literacy and skill, and 3) best practices for implementing a CURE in a biology class and engaging faculty for institutional transformation. Findings will be communicated through a UWF Coquina CURE web page that will incorporate content created by both students and faculty to share curriculum materials. Research results will be disseminated through peer-reviewed publications and conference presentations.  This project is being jointly funded by the Directorate for Biological Sciences, Division of Biological Infrastructure and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education as part of their efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education: A Call to Action (http://visionandchange.org/finalreport/).

por.por_cntn:
The primary goals of this project are to:

1. Increase transfer students' sense of belonging to UWF through the creation of a 4-week summer research program for incoming transfer students, and the conversion of the junior-level Genetics and Cell Biology laboratories to CUREs. 

Through this funding, we implemented 4-week and 3-week summer research programs targeted at transfer students called BIO-CoRE (Biology Coquina Research Experience). 28 students participated in these programs over three summers. The programs were highly successful in measures. For example, transfer students who participated in the BIO-CORE showed a statistically significant reduction in transfer shock and a drop in students' post-transfer GPA compared to transfer students who did not participate in the programs. Moreover, survey collection data showed gains in transfer students' sense of belonging at UWF compared to students who did not participate in these programs.

2. To increase transfer students' academic and scientific skills through cell biology and genetics CUREs

We completely transformed the cell biology, and genetics teaching labs into course-based undergraduate research experiences (CUREs) focused on the biology of the local coquina clam. We assessed the effectiveness of the CUREs through two independent measures and found that students who participated in the CUREs exhibited gains in academic and research skills. In addition, a CURE reflection survey and focus group analysis demonstrated that students who participated in the CURE overwhelmingly felt an increased sense of connection to the local research community and gains in research and academic skills that will help them in their future course work at UWF and beyond.

 

 

3. To increase the number of UWF biology faculty/staff (contingent and full-time) that participate in CUREs

We offered three years of a 1-week faculty CURE development workshop. Four junior faculty, one instructor, and eight graduate students participated in these workshops. As a result of the workshops, the Department of Biology expanded CURE development into several upper division labs. For example, the immunology, microbiology, and molecular labs revised the curriculum to develop CUREs. In addition, the Department was able to create novel teaching labs based on particular topics.

4. To discover and report new scientific knowledge about Donax variabilis (coquina clam) biology. 

We made significant progress in investigating the coquina clam. No other group has used this clam as a model organism before, so we learned a lot of new techniques and protocols for how to study them. We were able to do a complete RNA-sequence database from the clam. In addition, several genes were investigated for their differences in expression in response to various abiotic factors in the environment. Finally, the coquina clam was used as a model organism to study oxidative stress. The investigators found that maintaining the coquina clam in isolation was quite difficult and that more work needed to be done on the aquaculture aspect of this exciting bivalve.

The Broader Impacts of this proposal were to develop CUREs to provide a framework that could increase students' academic and research skills and train faculty on CURE development for institutional sustainability and transformation. We believe we have achieved these broader impacts at UWF. Before the grant, only one upper division lab was being taught as a CURE, and now we have about four per semester that are run as CUREs. In addition, we have begun hiring a full-time introductory lab coordinator to transform our introductory biology labs into CUREs. Our faculty have seen the benefits of combining their research into the teaching labs and how effective it can be for faculty and students. In addition, our programs have gotten the attention of others within the institution. We have given several talks across campus, and there are several grant proposals and industry partnerships in development as a result of this funding. In summary, these NSF-funded programs have had a significant transformational impact on our Department and University.

 


Last Modified: 07/19/2022
Modified by: Peter J Cavnar
